newsitem.title: USA: OPTIONS - T-bond vols climb ahead of busy week.
newsitem.headline: OPTIONS - T-bond vols climb ahead of busy week.

text.p: Implied volatility for September U.S. Treasury bond futures rose Friday as traders' focus turned to next week's heavy data lineup.
One options trader said volatility was attracting a bid before Tuesday's second-quarter employment cost index report.
"I can't think why else we'd be up on a Friday when we haven't moved," the trader said in the afternoon, when the underlying futures were languishing at slightly lower levels.
Typically, traders discount volatility on Friday afternoon to allow for weekend time decay.
However, the market is gearing up for a big week ahead. Also on the agenda are June new home sales Wednesday, second-quarter advance gross domestic product Thursday and July employment Friday.
Another trader said futures' late slide, back toward session lows at the close, may have contributed to the volatility uptick.
September bond volatility ended the session at 8.07 percent, up from 7.88 percent on the opening and from the previous settlement of 7.68 percent, according to one desk.
The futures contract ended at 115-01/32, down 9/32.

Some sizable transactions were noted in the 114-00 puts. Early in the session, a dealer firm sold 2,000 of the puts covered against futures at 115-06. The dealer also sold 4,000 of the 114-00 puts and bought 2,000 of the 115-00 puts in a spread.
A second dealer bought 2,500 of the 114-00 puts, and a local house bought 1,000.
In general, out-of-the-money put premiums have been depressed by an imbalance of sellers due to the current rally in futures, the first trader said.
At the short end of the curve, Eurodollar volatilities were flat to a touch firmer, with December pegged at 9.0 percent and March at 11.0 percent.
A Eurodollar options broker said good put buying interest continued for a second day.
He added the session's highlight was a trading firm's sale of 3,000 December 1998 straddles in the 93.75 strike around midday.
